major_name: Mathematical Optimization - Operations Research Specialization (Bachelor of Mathematics - Honours)
topics: Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and

Formulations of combinatorial optimization problems, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, branch-and-bound, cutting plane algorithms, decomposition techniques in integer programming, approximation algorithms.
A discrete optimization problem, broadly speaking, involves a discrete set of feasible solutions and a real-valued objective function that assigns a value to each solution.

topics: Formulation of problems as integer linear programs.

Introduction to the theory of valid inequalities and polyhedral combinatorics.
Integer Programming is a mathematical program that can be seen as a linear program with the additional requirement that some (or all) of the variables are required to take on integer values.

While linear programming is already very useful in modeling problems and can be solved well using either interior point methods or the simplex method, {\bf Integer programs, or IPs} have a much broader range of applications.
In this course we will explore an upper-level undergraduate/basic graduate introduction to the topic of Integer Programming.

topics: Introduction to Game Theory Fall 2024
A broad introduction to game theory and its applications to the modeling of competition and cooperation in business, economics, and society.
Classical game theory studies the competitive and cooperative behaviour of rational and self‐interested individuals in strategic environments.
It speciﬁcally develops beautiful analytic tools to analyze and model situations in which a person’s welfare is a function not only of their own actions, but also those of others.
This course is meant to be a broad and mathematical introduction to game theory and its appications.

Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and

course_name: AMATH251 - Introduction to Differential Equations (Advanced Level) (0.50)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Differential Equations (Advanced Level)
Email: cbauch@uwaterloo.ca
Email: apunnavajhala@uwaterloo.ca
This course offers a more theoretical treatment of differential equations and solution methods.
In addition, emphasis will be placed on computational analysis of differential equations and on applications in science and engineering.
Newton's enthusiasm was due to his success in using differential equations to give the first mathematical description of planetary orbits.

Can you imagine what his reaction would be to the present widespread use of differential equations, with applications ranging from the space shuttle guidance system to epidemic models and neural networks?
learn how to solve simple differential equations
understand how differential equations can be applied in various fields
We will cover portions of the following chapters from Boyce & DiPrima, in order:
Chapter 1: Introduction to DEs
Chapter 2: First-order differential equations
Chapter 3: Second-order differential equations
Chapter 7: Systems of linear equations
Chapter 8: Numerical methods
Chapter 9: Nonlinear differential equations and stability
Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value problems.

Introduction to Real Analysis Fall 2024

Topics discussed include the completeness properties of the reals; the density of the rationals; the topology of real n-dimensional space: open and closed sets, connectedness, compactness (by open covers), the Heine-Borel theorem, completeness; sequences in real n-dimensional space: convergence, Cauchy sequences, subsequences, the Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem; multivariable functions: limits, point-wise and uniform continuity, the extreme value theorem, uniform convergence of sequences of functions, Taylor's theorem, term-by-term differentiation of power series; integration in real n-dimensional space: Riemann integrability, Fubini's theorem for continuous functions on rectangles, term-by-term integration of power series.

Complex Analysis Winter 2025
Complex numbers provide the natural setting in which to study differentiable functions.

Cauchy's theorem plays a central role in this subject, and many important results follow from it: Cauchy's integral formula, the theory of Taylor and Laurent series, Cauchy's residue theorem, the argument principle, the fundamental theorem of algebra, the maximum modulus theorem, Mittag-Lefler expansions, and Weierstrass products.

We’ll start the course with a basic review of complex numbers, and the complex exponential and logarithm, complex analytic functions, and make our way towards Cauchy's theorem and its wonderful consequences.
My lectures will draw on a number of books and sources, but I recommend Knopp's Elements of the Theory of Functions, and his Theory of Functions Parts I and II.
Another reference is Marsden and Hoffman's Basic Complex Analysis.

Introduction to Differential Equations Winter 2025
Solving linear differential equations: first- and second-order scalar equations and first-order vector equations.
The main purpose of the course is to explore how first and second order differential equations (DEs) are used to model physical systems and predict their behaviour.
first order linear DE models of compartment problems, atomic decay, and bodies in motion;
first order separable DE models of population growth;
a first order exact DE model of the electric dipole;
second order linear DE models for oscillatory systems such as mass-spring-damper systems and electrical circuits;
second order nonlinear DE models for suspended cables and rocket motion;
linear vector DE models of multiple compartment problems and species interactions.
Both analytical solution techniques and qualitative methods (direction field analysis, dimensional analysis, and phase portraits) will be presented as ways to gain information about system behaviour.
We will investigate conditions for existence, uniqueness, and continuity of solutions of both first and second order initial value problems, and for systems in the plane.
Maple will be used to generate numerical and graphical solutions, to illustrate concepts graphically, and to explore model behaviour.
increase your comprehension of some of the many ways that differential equations can help us understand the real world;
develop your ability to understand a mathematical model for a specific situation;
explore analytical and qualitative solution methods for first and second order differential equations, and the use of Maple; and

An introductory course in physics for students intending to concentrate their future studies in the physical sciences, optometry, or mathematics; includes vectors (dot and cross products), particle kinematics and dynamics, forces in nature, work and energy, conservation of energy and linear momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics, and conservation of angular momentum.
Doing Physics - quantities, dimensions, units
Point Dynamics - force, motion, Newton's laws
Conservation of Energy - work and energy, conservative systems
Conservation of linear Momentum - momentum and systems of particles
Understand the following concepts:
- Linear kinematics: the relationship between distance, velocity and acceleration.
- Linear dynamics: a consequence of forces and momentum, and how they interrelate.
- Kinetic energy, potential energy, work, and their interrelationships.
We will also re-examine these concepts in a rotating coordinate frame using angular kinematic variables along with torque and angular momentum.

This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.
